children.subject: Correct.
The L&S's update is also for next semester, so we can PNP non-declaration classes and they will count towards CS major in Spring 2021 as well, right? Thanks.
Correct.
<md>Just to confirm, this also includes CS grad courses (e.g. CS270, CS262A) that have been approved for the computer science major?</md>
Yes, as long as they are approved.
So to confirm again, I can PNP CS lower divs and upper divs other than declaration classes and they’ll still be eligible for the major?
I've heard that CoE isn't following like L&S. I might be wrong but word of mouth is that they'll review the blue/green petition case by case, so no PNP option for any CoE students.

edit:
Currently, CoE and EECS aren't allowing P/NP:

https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/covid/covid-19-accommodations-and-support/
This post is for L&S CS. EECS students will receive information from Engineering Student Services soon.
Doesn;t look like they rejected PNP tho

As an aside, it would be so infuriating if CoE/EECS doesn't provide the same accommodations when the coursework is so similar to that of several majors in L&S, and when the pandemic doesn't discriminate based on your college or your major.

This is from the ESS newsletter that just went out:
This week the college undergraduate study committee will be making recommendations to the CoE faculty regarding temporary changes to course grading policy and baccalaureate requirements due to COVID-19 and remote learning. The entire CoE faculty will then vote to adopt one or more of these proposed changes. We expect to be able to announce these changes no later than Friday 11/20. Please do not contact your ESS adviser about course grading policies before this announcement.
Is there any timeline for the decision for EECS students?
See L&S' website. They modified the deadline to change your grading option to 12/4.
No not the deadline. I meant that I've already late-dropped a class this very semester. So are we allowed to late-chage grading on a class in the same semester as we have late-dropped another class?
yes i believe so - although it might be a good idea to email your adviser to confirm. As far as I'm aware, the late change limits (or one time late change policy) does not apply to these semesters.
Yes. You can do more than one late change, and it won't count as your once in a lifetime late change that it normally would at this point.
I already used the late change this sem to drop a class. Does this mean I can't P/NP a class?
This would be a general P/NP question that should be directed to L&S. See above link.
Do breadth classes taken at community college as P/NP count towards the 1/3 of total units taken P/NP.

I can’t edit above, but reason I ask is because some people may not need/want P/NP for those classes and then it seems fair to honor the same criteria as earlier for those people without any additional requirements prior to declaring. So, would any additional requirement only impact those who do P/NP any of the three classes to declare?

If you do not P/NP any of the declaration classes and meet the 3.3 GPA, we would declare you like usual. Make sure you submit your application by Dec 30th at 11:59PM, if you're taking your last prereq this semester.

You will not be forced to take anything P/NP.
Can we be assured that if you don’t use P/NP on any of 61A, 61B, 70 we can declare without anything additional? So basically, that we can still follow the old policy if we don’t use P/NP?
Classes for the CS minor may be taken for P/NP during Spring and Fall 2020, and Spring 2021. Updated the post. Thanks for checking.
What is the decision on the CS Minor? The minor isn't capped, so I would assume there would be no issue to PNP classes. Would I be able to PNP 61C to declare the minor?
We can't answer any questions on PNP for major declaration until the faculty have decided on a policy.
If I’m currently talking my last prereq for declaring and my previous two’s combined gpa < 3.3, will I have to take this class letter grade?
Correct. Updated post.
Just making sure but these policies hold for both Fall 2020  and Spring 2021, right?
no
Do the classes taken PNP in Spring 2020 count towards our 1/3 PNP limit?
yes, it says any non-declaration classes including upper-divs can be PNP, basically just not 61A, 61B and 70
yeah thanks, I really need to learn how to read xD
What about CS upper-divs? Can we take those PNP?
"We can't answer any questions on PNP for major declaration until the faculty have decided on a policy."
Would a possible policy be that we are allowed to P/NP one of 61A/61B/70?

A D- or higher is passing, as long as your lower/upper-div GPA in CS remains at a 2.0 or higher. An NP is not passing and will not count toward your CS requirements, even if it were in the D range. If you believe you are going to receive a grade in the D range, it is safer to stick with the letter graded option. **Always speak with your professor if you have concerns about your grade, especially during COVID.**
If you end up with an NP in a class you needed to graduate for CS, please email cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu ASAP.
Thanks!

If it looks like well get below a C- in an upper div CS course (any type of D), is it better to take the letter grade so we still receive credit for the course. If we take it PNP and get a D, then we'll get a NP, but for a letter grade we would still receive credit.

Am I correct?
It will disappear and we won't know you started to take it.
If I late drop one of the 61A, 61B, or 70 this semester or spring semester, will this adversely affect my declaration GPA if I take the class? Or will it be as if I never took it?
According to the update link, yeah for both.
We spoke to L&S on Friday, and the 1/3 limit is a university policy that they can't change, so yes, they do count.
Do the classes taken for PNP in this semester count towards the 1/3 pnp unit limit? Also there is no limit on how many classes we can take for PNP this semester, right?

The summer instructors have not heard anything about P/NP policies, so I think it's safe to assume it's going to be treated like a non-COVID semester. I believe the rationale in the summer was that "people know what they're signing up for" (I don't necessarily agree, but that's what we were told).
We don't have any information on summer. Please check with L&S.

This is from the ESS newsletter that just went out:
This week the college undergraduate study committee will be making recommendations to the CoE faculty regarding temporary changes to course grading policy and baccalaureate requirements due to COVID-19 and remote learning. The entire CoE faculty will then vote to adopt one or more of these proposed changes. We expect to be able to announce these changes no later than Friday 11/20. Please do not contact your ESS adviser about course grading policies before this announcement.

Just wanted to throw it out there. 
What's happening with the summer classes? Is it just what it is as of right now? It kind of seems unfair that students who took summer classes don't get this option.

Updates will be posted as soon as we have them (weekends and after-hours excluded). 
I recommend signing up for your best guess and then you can switch as soon as your Phase II appointment starts, if needed.
Hi, is there any update for P/NP for pre-reqs? The deadline for phase 1 is today, so I would love if we got news about the pre-reqs by then

Last semester the decision was made at the campus level while this semester it's being made at the college level, which suggests to me that students will need to take the initiative themselves. Not 100% sure though

According to this paragraph in the update:

We are still working through how to implement these policy changes. It might take a week or more to work through how some parts will be processed. Some changes will be done through Cal Central, while we are exploring the opportunity for some other operations to be completed via an online form or petition. 

It seems like it's unclear right now, but if you have decided what you want to do, I would go ahead and make any changes. You have until December 4, if you need to change anything back, but I wouldn't wait for L&S to do it for you if you have made up your mind.
Ok thanks!
Does anyone know how we're supposed to PNP classes? Last semester everything was automatically set to PNP so are we supposed to wait for that or submit the late change of grading option?
This post is for L&S CS. Please speak with your ESS Advisor.

This is from the ESS newsletter that just went out:
This week the college undergraduate study committee will be making recommendations to the CoE faculty regarding temporary changes to course grading policy and baccalaureate requirements due to COVID-19 and remote learning. The entire CoE faculty will then vote to adopt one or more of these proposed changes. We expect to be able to announce these changes no later than Friday 11/20. Please do not contact your ESS adviser about course grading policies before this announcement.
What about for engineering school students? Would students within the college of engineering still have to take all courses with letter grades?
I would defer to the L&S guidelines for that. I believe they did mention something about R&C in their email.
Are we also permitted to take other L&S requirement (reading and composition, for example) PNP?
This is a better question for the L&S advisors. There's a link above for how to contact them.

Wait the 1/3 policy refers to no more than 1/3 of our classes at time of graduation can be PNP right? We could, in theory, PNP everything this semester as long as we are under 1/3 at time of graduation?
any updates?
We hope by end of this week, but it might not be until next week.
when can we expect a policy on l&s cs major declaration?
have there been any updates?
Please see above. We will notify students as soon as we can.
^ would like to know about updates as well
They literally just said that they'll notify students as soon as they can, with the hope of doing so next week if not sooner
any progress about declaration policy so far?
No. https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/policies/grading-options-letter-graded-and-passno-pass
thank you!
Will we be put on academic probation if we take all classes as PNP?
We are not able to see the enrollment system in the same way that students can, but yes, you need to change the grading option yourself by end of day on Dec 4th. This will not happen automatically.

I'm not sure if I'm interpreting the instructions on the L&S page correctly. If I intend only to change the grading option of one of my classes to PNP, then do I have to submit the form in addition to changing the grading option manually above, or is just changing the option sufficient? The instructions imply that I need to submit the form in addition, but the Late Schedule Change Request seems to only be for drops.

I'd feel more comfortable if L&S could talk you through the process since this is their policy. They have Virtual Front Desk hours: https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/appointments-advice/virtual-front-desk.

Thank you, I got my question answered by them and they stated you can either use the form or manually change it yourself, and you don't need to do both. The caveat is that manually changing it yourself closes a day earlier on December 3rd.
Oh, good to know! Thanks!
So if we've reached 120 units, does it mean we can PNP all classes in the Spring as well? It shows on the P/NP calculator on CalCentral that we can do that. Just want to confirm.. Thanks.
Please check with L&S.

How can we change a class to PNP? Do we need to do it ourselves by choosing the option attached and change our option grade to Elective Pass/No Pass? Below is the image if my understanding is correct. Could advisor please confirm? Thanks.

The original post is for L&S CS/CS-intended students. 
COE students can refer to this update from Friday: https://engineering.berkeley.edu/students/covid/pnp-policy-2020-21/, but please do not ask follow-up questions here as this post is for L&S students.
Are we allowed to opt for P/NP of CS-70 if we're planning to declare as an EECS major in CoE?
Yes, this is OK for the CS minor. Yes, that is the deadline: https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/policies/late-change-class-schedule
To clarify, we can P/NP all cs courses if we are a CS minor, and the last day to do that is 12/4 (Friday) 11:59pm? Thanks!

You could do either one of the options you listed, but for CS unless you have a background in physics/circuits it probably makes more sense for you to do EECS 16A since you need to take EECS 16B. https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-lowerdiv#after_2017
<md>Hi Lydia, can we P/NP graduate courses (e.g. CS262A) that count toward upper division requirements this semester? They were not explicitly mentioned so I just want to make sure. Thank you.</md>
Yes, if approved.

Thank you Lydia.

One more question:
If I leave Math 54 as a NP grade and take Math EECS 16A, when declaring a CS major will they look at both Math 54 and EECS16A (thus compromising my declaration) or just look at EECS16A?
<md>CS declaration only takes into account CS61A, CS61B, and CS70. Math54/EECS16A grade is not considered.</md>
thanks poet! Was just concerned since it was just required
What happens if I P/NP Math 54, and don't pass the class? Should I retake it during the summer or take Math EE16A?

From the L&S website:

Late Change of Class Schedule Deadline: 

Late grading option changes and late drops can be made up until the Late Change of Class Schedule Deadline:

FALL 2020: December 4, 2020 at 11:59pm PT

No requests for late changes to class schedules will be considered after this deadline.
What has been modified is that the grading option change deadline is also this Friday and the late drops do not count toward an L&S' student's one-semester late change action.
<md>The deadline for the one time late change of class schedule before was the Friday of RRR week, is it now the Friday before RRR week too?</md>
Please see above and check in with L&S.
How does the 1/3 PNP calculation work? Do you take all your units taken at Berkeley and just take 1/3 of that and as long as you are under that threshold you're still good for graduation?

Oops. Apparently I never hit post. For the CS major, there is no limit during Spring 2020, Fall 2020, and Spring 2021 for how many classes you can take P/NP. Note that classes taken for P/NP during Spring 2020 do not count toward your 1/3 limit, but classes taken for P/NP during Fall 2020 & Spring 2021 do. See L&S' website for more PNP info.
Is there a limit to how many upper-div courses we can PNP? Also are you not allowed to PNP all your classes?
Can I take non-CS upper divs P/NP for the 6-units outside major department requirement? (Fall 2021)

history.content:
Dear L&S CS Students,

L&S sent an update on 11/5/20 regarding Pass/Not Pass grading policies for Fall 2020 and Spring 2021. The EECS faculty have crafted a policy on how this impacts the CS major declaration classes (CS61A, CS61B, and CS70) taken during these semesters. The policy is detailed in post @13692.

Non-declaration classes for the CS major taken during Spring 2020, Fall 2020, and Spring 2021, (Math 1A, Math 1B, CS61C, EECS 16A/Math 54, EECS 16B, and upper-division classes), may be taken for P/NP. Instructions on how to change your grading option this semester are here.

Classes for the CS minor taken during Spring 2020, Fall 2020, and Spring 2021 may also be taken for P/NP. 

Taking CS major/minor classes for P/NP will still fulfill prerequisites for subsequent classes in EECS.

Note the APR will not understand this new policy. We don't use the APR for CS anyway (@8853), so that's OK. Make an appointment in CalCentral or email us for a degree check.

Send us questions at cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu. Refer to L&S' update and L&S advising for general P/NP questions.

Take care, Everyone!

CS Advisors

Take care, Everyone!
